conclusion: The images show the concept of a diver looking up from water and seeing everything compressed into a cone with angle α.
When a diver is underwater looking up, they see the above-water world compressed into a cone with vertex angle α due to refraction at the water-air interface.
The second figure shows that light rays striking the water surface at angle α/2 refract to travel horizontally along the water's surface.
Snell's law relates the angles of incidence and refraction to the refractive indices of the two media.
The incident angle in water is α/2 and the refracted angle in air is 90° for the critical angle case.
For the critical angle case, Snell's law gives n_water sin(α/2) = 1, leading to n_water = 1/sin(α/2).
The refractive index is related to the speed of light by n = c/v.
The speed of light in water is v_water = c * sin(α/2).
The propagation speed of light in water is v_water = c * sin(α/2), where c is the speed of light in vacuum and α is the vertex angle of the cone seen by the diver.
